#Text=Prepare Your Computer for Gaming Use
#Text=Welcome to a brief tutorial on how to squeeze every last bit of performance out of your computer , for gaming .
#Text=This is going to be strictly software based and will show you ways to fine tune your system to get slight performance increases without having to buy new hardware .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Now the first thing I always like to do when I get my hands on a new system , is to do a clean install of whichever Windows system is newest .
#Text=So in this case I would make a bootable flash drive using the official Windows 10 ISO , and placing it onto a flash drive using the Rufus application .
#Text=Now after the system has had a clean install , with no bloatware or other pre-loaded junk that hardware manufactuers love to load onto our systems .
#Text=It 's always a good idea to run the disk cleanup , as well as defrag and optimize the disk .
#Text=These programs can be found and launched in the " Windows administrative tools " folder .

column1: #Text=Now you can access what we need in this next step by clicking on the little batter icon on the far right side of the Windows taskbar , and select " more power options " .
#Text=This should take you to a control panel window with options for " powersaver mode " and " balanced mode " , as well as a hidden third option .

column1: #Text=To get to this hidden option you will need to click the little dropdown icon on the far right of the window .
#Text=You 'll see an option come down called " High performance mode " .

column1: #Text=Which will typically keep restrictions on your processor state off regardless of the battery life ( assuming you have a laptop ) .
#Text=Next up you want to access your control panel and go to System and Security > System > Advanced System Settings in the far left toolbar .
#Text=This will open up a new , smaller window for system properties .
#Text=Click the settings button under performance and click the circle choice for " Adjust for best performance " , apply and click " OK " to exit the window .
#Text=Next thing is the most important .
#Text=Find out what graphics card you have .
#Text=It 'll let you know where to go in order to get updates for the graphics card driver , which will help your system better take advantage of your video card 's resources .
#Text=If you 're really scrimping for system memory then I would suggest downloading Razer Cortex ( formally known as game booster ) .

#Text=It not only can dynamically shut down processes when a game launches , but it also has some great tweak tools to adjust system settings that are generally harder to find , which can lead to some more performance increases .
#Text=Now , some more steps to take are to clean up your system and just generally do some housekeeping work on it from time to time .

#Text=Keep as few items on the desktop as possible ( I typically only keep the recycle bin icon on my desktop ) , clean out your downloads folder whenever you can , and organize any files you use constantly .
#Text=Running the defrag tools periodically wo n't hurt either .
#Text=Make sure ALL of your drivers are up to date .
#Text=You never understand how important an updated Wifi driver is until you experience lag spikes and performance issues with any kind of online game .
#Text=Make sure you know what is running in the background at all times .
#Text=Not only is it a good rule of thumb , but also , I ca n't tell you how many times I 've had to quit or alt+tab out of a game to turn off Google Chrome when it was running in the background .
#Text=Finally , restart your computer every now and then .
#Text=Do n't just leave the thing going on for days , even weeks on end .
#Text=I 'd say at least once a day just run a restart , it 'll let the system dump some loose data and get a fresh start .
